The writings of a satirist may easily leave us in doubt as to the events os his life: it is not certain that they will impress us with the character of the writer, or even that they will be, so far as they go, a trustworthy representation os his habitual sels. We nray reckon with more confidence upon finding traces ol his personal ideas which are often distinctive, even when the character is commonplace3 we may be sure of getting a tolerably complete view ol the points at which life bore hardly upon the class and the generation which the satirist represents.
